name: Alex Morcos

name: Alex Morcos

name: Alex Morcos
tweet: I‚Äôm with Cobra here.  It‚Äôs a bad situation and he has tried to do why he thinks is best. Outside observers shouldn‚Äôt underestimate the damage Craig and Calvin are causing.

name: Alex Morcos
tweet: @twobitidiot Probably no one really likes everything about it or where it‚Äôs going or perhaps to your point not going.  But that‚Äôs also it‚Äôs greatest value. It‚Äôs really hard to influence at all.

name: Alex Morcos
Alex Morcos
tweet: Mining and the bitcoin blockchain should be a neutral service and should not be "inspecting" transactions to the degree thats possible.  It's a shortcoming of Bitcoin that that is even possible for miners to do.

name: Alex Morcos
tweet: It's probably even more directly "tainted" than that.  All those transactions include coins that originally came from coinbases, most of which included fees derived from 1000's of transactions in other blocks.   It's almost like trying to track the electrons that power your home.

name: Alex Morcos
tweet: @nfosec19 @brucefenton @Kirupapushparaj There are a lot of orgs trying to help Bitcoin.  The more the better.  No one or even group of them has any official standing or ever will.

name: Alex Morcos
tweet: @nfosec19 @brucefenton @Kirupapushparaj ok.  i see this as a much narrower scope.  i don‚Äôt think they are looking to be some sort of official representative of Bitcoin and even if they ever did try to do that, I don‚Äôt see anyone giving them that authority.

name: Alex Morcos
tweet: @OryCarter its one thing to require the KYC/AML procedures, but its another to say there is absolutely no way to pay with self-custodied coins.

name: Alex Morcos
tweet: @LukeDashjr @Excellion @MrHodl That‚Äôs patently false.  The assumption is MASF is going to succeed.  If you are writing mission critical code what do you do if an assumption turns out to be wrong? If you had the option to pause everything and rethink you‚Äôd obviously take that.  You don‚Äôt just charge ahead.

name: Alex Morcos
tweet: @bergealex4 @Excellion @MrHodl Maybe you're right on that point.  Seems to me many aren't as sanguine as you are about Core releasing the mechanism they feel is best though.

name: Alex Morcos
tweet: @bergealex4 @Excellion @MrHodl Thats the kind of scenario I'd like to avoid.  It's a consensus split for no good reason.   Why?   If you want to lock in a UASF now if the MASF fails, do it far enough in the future that everyone else can still choose to join you if the MASF fails.

name: Alex Morcos
tweet: @bergealex4 @Excellion @MrHodl we now have some significant minority of the network running LOT=true so their date is already set, but the vast majority of installed software needs a new activation mechanism and we're running out of time to safely implement and deploy that for the date fixed in the old one.

name: Alex Morcos
tweet: @bergealex4 @Excellion @MrHodl So what do you think about this scenario then? For whatever reason MASF doesn't activate, maybe just a few too many miners don't bother.  Consensus at that point is we should just UASF to get Taproot because there is no real opposition.  However...

name: Alex Morcos
tweet: @bergealex4 @Excellion @MrHodl Sure eventually you may have to do that.  But it was unnecessarily rushed then and not even needed now.

name: Alex Morcos
tweet: @bergealex4 @Excellion @MrHodl Thats what happened with UASF, and we ran the risk of a real fork before BIP 91 brought some stability.  I would have rather had the outcome guaranteed more slowly and consensus more clearly built than the high stakes posturing.

name: Alex Morcos
tweet:
@bergealex4 @Excellion @MrHodl That's mostly right.  I need to think through it, but I'm not sure providing a config option is the right thing. But easy enough for someone to code up and release lot=true also.

Individuals doing lot=true is risky imo, but sure, that should be their own choice to make.

name: Alex Morcos
tweet: @bergealex4 @Excellion @MrHodl The equivalence I find is in trying to bully people. Bitcoin should default to stability; less radical and slower change. We all agree we should upgrade if MASF works, we have not yet all agreed to UASF if it doesn't. Trying to force it through in the face of obvious opposition?

name: Alex Morcos
tweet: @Excellion @MrHodl That's so backwards. Of course devs should not make peoples decision. But if everyone just makes their own decision without trying to agree with everyone else, then you might as well switch to BU's Emergent Consensus.  So I think its obvious the "faster" people should wait..

name: Alex Morcos
tweet: @Excellion @MrHodl The only reason to want LOT=true is if you're trying to dispel the notion that miners control the rules. No one believes that. You're still fighting the last battle. This isn't BSV or BCH, it's BTC. Instead of focusing on that, focus on conservative changes and stability.

name: Alex Morcos
tweet: @MrHodl @Excellion That wasn't the alternative. The alternative was not to turn it into a game of chicken and instead activate segwit some amount of time later once tempers had cooled and industry had come around.

name: Alex Morcos
tweet: @MrHodl @Excellion I agree they do. I also agree it shouldn't be a big deal. But it's exactly as if a significant group wanted to delay the activation date. Shouldn't that be the default. Go with the slower version.

name: Alex Morcos
tweet: @Excellion @MrHodl how silly can you be?   it‚Äôs not devs.  it‚Äôs the community agreeing on what rules PoW applies to.   LOT=T or F are 2 different rule sets.  We‚Äôve agreed on 99% of Taproot rules but not on that last part just because some yahoo twitterers think they are sticking it to miners.

name: Alex Morcos
tweet: @Excellion I disagree.  I think rejecting 2X was that.  And proceeding with segwit anyway was the right thing.  The specifics of UASF were a clown show.  But the term UASF has come to refer to the larger story.  Not the reckless technical details.

name: Alex Morcos
tweet: @Excellion I am an outside observer here, I don‚Äôt have much to do with development any more.  But I can‚Äôt imagine that you honestly think not discussing is the right outcome.  UASF was almost a disaster just as 2X.  You are the ones agitating for the controversial forced change.  Again.

name: Alex Morcos
tweet: @Excellion The alternative is to release no default and have software that doesn‚Äôt keep consensus with itself?  That sounds like pretty much the whole thing we‚Äôre trying to avoid

name: Alex Morcos
tweet: @hampus_s @bergealex4 @danrobinson @Excellion exactly.  so LOT=false is sufficient.  we would only need LOT=true if we don‚Äôt have overwhelming consensus because miners aren‚Äôt on board and then it becomes a bigger question

name: Alex Morcos
tweet: @LukeDashjr @francispouliot_ @danrobinson @Excellion LOT=false just means it doesn't activate without miners active consent for now.  That's it.  "for now".  That seems a very good default to try if you ask me.  If miners are not actively consenting to it, we should ask why and proceed from there.

name: Alex Morcos
tweet: @LukeDashjr @francispouliot_ @danrobinson @Excellion or course not. it verifies for the one group for which you can easily verify.  verifying some is better than verifying none.

name: Alex Morcos
tweet: @LukeDashjr @francispouliot_ @danrobinson @Excellion Why are you spreading misinformation?  How would trying LOT=false allow miners to cancel it permanently? It brings forward the heat death of the universe by a googol years? LOT=false just gives us more options if our current assumptions prove incorrect.

name: Alex Morcos
tweet: @midmagic @francispouliot_ @danrobinson @Excellion well i imagine it's more like a community consensus that we need to delay, that they can just implement for us without requiring a hard fork.

name: Alex Morcos
tweet: @francispouliot_ @danrobinson @Excellion OK, I don't think its worth engaging in this any more.  Just note that you are trying to force through a change over objections.  You can justify that all you want, but in my opinion the default should almost always be no change.

name: Alex Morcos
tweet: @francispouliot_ @danrobinson @Excellion But it also provides an important safety valve... what happens if we discover some other large part of the community isn't on board, or serious bugs when everyone implements, or anything similar.  Then miners can help safely delay.

name: Alex Morcos
tweet: @francispouliot_ @danrobinson @Excellion Exactly the point. It's the way you verify that everyone is on board. (or at least those you can) If they "veto" it, then you've discovered that not everyone was on board, and so you have to reevaluate with this new information.  Likely it just leads to an unfortunate delay.

name: Alex Morcos
tweet: @francispouliot_ @danrobinson @Excellion I don't understand.  We're not.  We're just trying it that way first.  What is the rush?

name: Alex Morcos
tweet: @francispouliot_ @danrobinson @Excellion I'd first want to understand why, and then make sure that the majority of the community wanted to activate it anyway, then I'd support a UASF.   We're not in that position.  There is no reason to believe anyone is adverse to this.  So lets proceed cooperatively.

name: Alex Morcos
tweet: @francispouliot_ @danrobinson @Excellion I want to base activate on the premise that virtually everyone has agreed to it.  Hashpower is one of the few things that can be quantitatively assessed and it also adds a safety factor in coordination.   If miners didn't activate Taproot, that would be very bad.

name: Alex Morcos
tweet: @francispouliot_ @danrobinson @Excellion Consensus changes should be slow and deliberate and err on the side of caution.  That's one thing that differentiates Bitcoin.  LOT=false should be the default, everyone is on board.   LOT=true should be for a worst case scenario.   We can always do that after if we need.

name: Alex Morcos
tweet: @francispouliot_ @danrobinson @Excellion My understanding is we think miners will activate it.  If they don't, thats new information we should take into account and then at that time decide as a community to activate it in spite of them.  I'm all for the idea of a UASF when necessary.

name: Alex Morcos
tweet: @danrobinson @Excellion Unfortunately the wrong lessons were learned from UASF.  The idea is super valuable.  Miners shouldn't have a unilateral veto. But also a group of users (or any group) shouldn't force through a change without overwhelming consensus.  BIP 91 saved us from this mess last time.

name: Alex Morcos
tweet: @Excellion This is incredibly disappointing.  There is absolutely no reason to LOT=true now.  None.  Zero reason.  Wanting this puts you in the same boat as Roger or the 2X crowd.  Trying to force everyone else into change they don't accept.  But its ok when you're the one doing it?

name: Alex Morcos
tweet: Craig Wright is inconsequential. But this sets a good a example of how Bitcoin should respond to threats. In a distributed manner, with strength in numbers, and not being reliant on any small group of individuals or organizations.
